10

MBTA fires trolley operator in Green Line crash

Officials said the driver who hit another train last week was inattentive and did not have enough rest after he worked an overnight shift at a second job. (Globe, 1:41 p.m.)
  • 11/30 Equipment failure ruled out in Green Line crash
  • 11/29 35 taken to hospital after two trolleys collide
  • YouTube Surveillance video of crash | Crash scenes

SJC: Police don't need warrant to view cellphone call list after an arrest

A unanimous Supreme Judicial Court said it would decide at another time if people had rights to privacy for other contents like texts and e-mails. (Globe, 1:28 p.m.)
  • Discuss What do you think of the SJC's ruling?

Warren ended Senate campaign in debt despite record $42 million fund-raising

After raising more than any other US congressional candidate, Elizabeth Warren said her campaign doesn't have enough cash to pay its bills. (Globe, 2:29 p.m.)

Mass. hunts an arsonist

State and local fire officials are hoping to put a quick end to the random torching of vacant buildings, homes, and sheds across Southeastern Mass.
Opinion | Brian McGrory

Bridge is lighting the way forward

Look for the newly lit Leonard P. Zakim Bridge by next ­Friday, not only a symbol of a new Boston, but a sign that government can get good things done.

Roger Williams’s shorthand decoded

Lucas Mason-Brown, 21, of Belmont, is part of a small team of students that cracked a previously undeciphered shorthand used by the founder of Rhode Island.
Opinion | Derrick Z. Jackson

Fracking is the new gold rush

The new, heady pursuit of oil, thanks to the reserves unleashed by fracking, raises the question: What will happen when the rush is gone?

Pension board OK’s bonus pay plan

The board of the Mass. state pension fund approved a compensation plan that will increase bonuses for investment staff and introduce hurdles for earning them.
Opinion | Jeff Jacoby

Grant’s greatest regret

In one of the great sagas of atonement in American life, Ulysses S. Grant went from being a scourge of the Jews to one of their greatest friends.

City Hall services go mobile

Residents can pay parking tickets and tax bills, get a library card and dog license, even register to vote, at a van dubbed “City Hall To Go.”

Cahill jury begins deliberations

A jury yesterday began deliberating corruption charges against former state treasurer Tim Cahill, who was portrayed at trial as an altruistic public servant but also as a scheming politician who used taxpayer-funded advertising for his sinking gubernatorial campaign.

Business

BAE receives contract for missile systems with N.H.-built parts

The global defense contractor said today that it has received $81 million from Lockheed Martin to begin production of 143 infrared seekers built in Nashua, N.H.
